history.content:
You'll need way more than 1 semester of work to be a quant. Honestly, econ 136, 138, 139 are decent for the financial side. On the modeling/math side i feel that stats classes should do better, although im sure someone else can give better guidance. I know a solid background in probability so stuff like stats 134, cs 70, and ee 126 should go a long way. You may have heard that many quants hire physics majors because of their ability to work with complex systems, but thats something that they (usually PHD's) have developed over more than a decade. Honestly, you really have to go out of your way and find resources and just try for these firms. Many of their interviews do not test "highly complex systems" but require a ridiculously strong grasp of a huge array of basic knowledge (which makes the field hard to get into). 

----

For a physics course, I would try whichever looks most interesting. The 7 series works with pretty simple systems (it certainly doesn't do any intense computational modeling), and EE classes are where you should go to understand the hardware behind computers, quantum computing is taught in CS 191. My thought was always that quants came from intense math backgrounds, and physicists have that background, and since physics majors tend to end up in a wide array of disciplines (this is a compliment, not a critique) many end up in quantitative finance and software engineering.

What basic knowledge is this?

history.content:
I'm not an eecs major, so I don't need to take physics, but I'm wondering if I should take a physics course. I want to go into quantitative finance, where - and I'm not sure about this - you're modeling and trying to understanding highly complex systems. This is exactly what physics teaches.

I also feel like physics would help me understand quantum computing and computers on the level of silicon and transistors.

Can you suggest me a one-semester course? I know about the physics 7a, 7b, 7c series but it's 3 semesters!
